What is called the Dharma of not being negligent?
It means always guarding and protecting the faculties.
What is meant by guarding and protecting the faculties?

It means that when the eyes see forms, one does not grasp at their characteristics, nor does one grasp at their wonderful aspects, nor does one become attached to the flavors of forms and so forth. One truly understands the Dharma of liberation.

In this way, when the ears hear sounds, the nose smells fragrances, the tongue experiences tastes, the body senses tactile objects, and the mind cognizes dharmas, one does not grasp at their characteristics, nor does one grasp at their wonderful aspects, nor does one become attached to the flavors of dharmas and so forth. One truly understands the Dharma of liberation.

Non-negligence means having already disciplined one's own mind and well protected the minds of others, removing afflictions and directly realizing the bliss of the Dharma, not observing anything, not observing thoughts of desire, anger, or harm, not observing the unwholesome roots of greed, anger, or delusion, not observing evil conduct of body, speech, or mind, not observing shallow and unstable attention, and in short, not observing any sinful unwholesome dharmas at all.
This is called non-negligence.

The bodhisattva of non-negligence deeply and firmly focuses his mind and diligently practices in accordance with the characteristics.
If a dharma exists, he knows it as it is; if a dharma does not exist, he knows it as it is.
What does it mean to exist?
What does it mean to not exist?
It means that diligent practice of the right path gives rise to faith and understanding, while diligent practice of the wrong path does not give rise to faith and understanding.
All karmas that have retribution exist, while all karmas that have no retribution do not exist;
The eye exists, while the true nature of the eye does not exist;
The ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind exist, while the true nature of the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind does not exist;

Form is impermanent, suffering, not ultimate, not solid, and subject to disintegration, so it exists; but to consider form as permanent, blissful, ultimate, solid, and not subject to disintegration does not exist;

Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are impermanent, suffering, not ultimate, not solid, and subject to disintegration, so they exist; but to consider feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness as permanent, blissful, ultimate, solid, and not subject to disintegration does not exist.
